FAQ.question: What are prohibited lands?
FAQ.answer: Prohibited lands are government-restricted properties that cannot be sold, transferred, or registered due to legal, public, religious, or administrative restrictions.

FAQ.question: What types of land are commonly marked as prohibited?
FAQ.answer: Examples include assigned land, endowment/temple land, government poramboke, forest land, tribal land, ceiling surplus land, defense land, irrigation land, and protected heritage land.

FAQ.question: Does a Sale Deed alone confirm whether land is prohibited?
FAQ.answer: No. A Sale Deed can be registered even on restricted land in some cases due to oversight, so classification must be verified separately through land records.

FAQ.question: Can prohibited land be regularized or converted?
FAQ.answer: In certain cases, reclassification or regularization may be possible through legal processes, subject to policy and authority approval.

FAQ.question: Does prohibited land appear in Encumbrance Certificate?
FAQ.answer: Not always. EC shows transactions, but prohibitions are classification-based and require revenue or statutory verification.

FAQ.question: Is all government land considered prohibited?
FAQ.answer: Most government land is non-transferable, but certain lands may be leased or allotted legally depending on jurisdiction and policy.

FAQ.question: Does prohibited status apply to both agricultural and non-agricultural land?
FAQ.answer: Yes. Restrictions apply based on classification, authority, or purpose, irrespective of land type.

FAQ.question: Will banks approve loans on prohibited land?
FAQ.answer: No. Most financial institutions reject loans on restricted lands because legal ownership cannot be established.

FAQ.question: Can prohibited status be verified online?
FAQ.answer: In many jurisdictions, yesâ€”classification datasets are linked to digital land records. JaaGa fetches this directly from official sources.

FAQ.question: Is prohibited land data from JaaGa authentic?
FAQ.answer: Yes. All classifications are fetched directly from official revenue, survey, and land authority portals without modification.
